content: Using multiple AI agents simultaneously can significantly increase efficiency, enabling tasks that would take 5 hours to be completed in 5 minutes.
Parallel agents are independent AI agents with their own context, memory, personalities, and separate interfaces, capable of communicating and sharing knowledge.
Parallel agents are analogous to having multiple employees with different roles reporting directly to you, who can communicate but do so infrequently unless their functions are closely related.
Sub-agents are temporary AI workers spawned and managed by a parallel agent for specific tasks.
Sub-agents do not retain memory, which is a feature that helps keep context windows clean.
Sub-agents are like department heads hiring and managing contractors on a project-by-project basis.
Use parallel agents when you need agents with different domains of expertise, such as a health coach, chief of staff, and marketing officer.
Employ parallel agents when direct and separate access to each agent with distinct chat records is desired, preventing conversation pollution between different topics.
Utilize parallel agents for redundancy and backup, as one operational agent can troubleshoot issues with another.

Assign different AI models to parallel agents based on the complexity and cost-effectiveness required for their specific jobs (e.g., Sonnet for coaching, Opus 4.5 for complex tasks, Gemini for writing).
Use sub-agents for batch or grunt work, such as organizing numerous tasks, to avoid using expensive models for overkill tasks and free up the main agent.
Deploy sub-agents for research tasks, like gathering user reviews and compiling reports, allowing the main agent to remain available for other duties.
Leverage sub-agents for cost savings by applying the most appropriate and cost-effective model for specific tasks, thereby reducing token usage.
Spawning sub-agents allows the main agent to remain free and assist with other tasks concurrently.
